intro: Enydra anagallis, commonly known as the common mouse-ear, is a flowering plant native to Europe and parts of Asia. It belongs to the family Boraginaceae and is characterized by its hairy, oval-shaped leaves and small, pink or purple flowers. The plant typically grows in dry, rocky soils and is often found in disturbed habitats such as roadsides and fields. It is an annual or short-lived perennial, with a low-growing habit and a distinctive seed capsule that releases tiny seeds when mature. The species is also known for its medicinal properties and has been used in traditional herbal remedies.
